instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPUâ€™s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a quarter fan spin
threads.message:
Hi guys,

first of all, thanks for taking a look at this. I've watched a lot of Louis's video's, but this is my first actual board I'm fixing. there was heavy liquid damage near the LCD connector, so i first replaced <CHIP>U9000</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7920</TRANSISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C9009</CAPACITOR>. The onewire circuit worked because i had/have a green light on the magsafe, but no fan spin. I diagnosed <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> not being present, so i replaced <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>. now I do have <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>, and my fan spins for a second before it stops, then starts again. that continues in a cycle. I also replaced <CAPACITOR>C6601</CAPACITOR> because I knocked the original off the board. Now the next signal that is not present is <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>. (I'm also missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>) and the corresponding s0 rails but that seems logical to me since i dont have the S3 rails. 

The part where I am stuck is this: 

from what I understand from the schematic, <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> creates <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>, but something has to happen with <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7261</TRANSISTOR>. Now what exactly that is, I don't know. I vaguely remember Louis has a video describing what an N channel mosfet is, I can't find the specific video anymore though. 

I do have 12.5v on pin 5 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR>. Some additional measurements: 
rail    should be   is    diode mode
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>    12.8    12.5    
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>    12.8    12.5    
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL>            
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>    3.42    3.47    
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>    3    3.30    
            
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>    5    5.01    
<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>    5    5    
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>    5    0    0.100
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>    5    0    
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>    3.3    3.3    
pp3v3s4    3.3    3.3    
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>    3.3    0    
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>    3.3    0    
            
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>    1.25    0    
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL>    1.05    0    
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3_CPU_VCCDQ</SIGNAL>            


Can anyone please point me in the right direction? Or knows what the video is where Louis explains the mosfets? Wikipedia and the likes only talk about substrates and chemical blablabla, which is all way above my college dropout mind. Thanks in advance!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a quarter fan spin
threads.message: Forgot something: I also replaced <CHIP>U5010</CHIP> because the pins were corroded. shielded the SMC ofcourse :p

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a quarter fan spin
threads.message: update: pin 2 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> has 3.44 volts when the fan doesn't spin. when the fan starts spinning it drops to 0v, and then back to 3.44

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a quarter fan spin
threads.message: also [COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=13px]<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is 0v at <TRANSISTOR>Q7911</TRANSISTOR>. hmm, that signal comes from the PCH. does that mean my PCH is bad? [/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a quarter fan spin
threads.message:
Check resistance between pins 17 and 18 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. If it measures 2.203 ohms or something close, move on. If it doesn't, fix it!

If <CHIP>U5010</CHIP> was corroded that means water got near <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>. Replace <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> as any amount of water, even amounts tiny enough to not cause visible corrosion, will destroy it.

These are the two most common causes of quarter fan spin on 2936/3115 boards.
